Nice dubbel, developed by the late Pierre Celis. It ages in bottles in the marl caves of Kanne (near Maastricht), 42 meter under the ground at a temperature of about 11 ° C. The bottles are placed here in so called pupiters and rotated regularly, a process that Celis copied from traditional champagne producers.

Bruna con un bel cappello di schiuma persistente, molto fine e che si attacca al bicchiere. Aroma davvero originale. Dolciastro, leggermente acidulo con alcune componenti tanniche, fruttate (amarena?) e floreali. Al palato ingresso davvero divertente e originale. Attacco dolce ma molto agile di bevuta. Cè un ritorno retrolfattivo di erbe, con un finale molto rinfrescante, tipo menta o citronella. Originale e davvero piacevole da bere.
Botella de 33 Cl. Cerveza de abdia muy facil de tomal y con una graduación alcoholica media.

aroma:  caramel, floral, banana, 
apparenza: brown, orange, cloudy, white foam, 
gusto: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, 
palato: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, abrupt finish
buona dubbel..aroma speciale,complesso..banana,malto,un pò di alcohol e qualcosaltro,probabilmente spezie o aromi sviluppati dai lieviti..birra ambrata/scura con schiuma non molto spessa ma persistente..gusto pieno,carbonazione media,dolce principalmente,con finale luppolato con una punta di acidità

Bottle from my large stash of Belgians, this one is a few years old. A dark murky brown coloured pour with a medium off white head on top. Sweet, caramel, dark fruit aroma. Tastes similar, sweet, dark fruit, caramel, spice. Nice Belgian dubbel.

Comprada en Cervezorama. Una de las mejores cervezas de su clase. Color rojizo oscuro, con buena espuma, turbia. En el aroma se adivina el alcohol que está quizá demasiado presente en el sabor. Postgusto largo, de fruta madura, con gran complejidad. Estupenda creación del creador de Hoegaarden.

33cl bottle from Gambrinus, during summer 2012. Excellent beer, with cellary aroma, that is enjoyable. Dense, thick brew. One of my favourite beers.  You cant drink more than a bottle - taste was overwhelming.

Pours opaque brown with creamy light tanned lace. Aromas of cherry, light acidity, typical st bernadus yeast, sweet malt character. Beautiful inviting aroma. Medium light body, a light acidity,sour, cherries, creamy carbonation. Finishes powdery, tasty and the acidity lightly lingers.

Bottled gift from SJ. Drank at xmas party 2012. (Sort of a Belgian night)

I enjoed this brew a lot. Nice notes of spices like cinnamon and clove. Nice toasted malt with toffee and dark raisins. Very good.

Bottle, 50 cl. Hazy red brown with a lively off white head. Aroma is dry malty, yeasty and spicey with fruity notes. Dryish spicy flavor with notes of yeast, plums, dried fruits and a whif of cicia. Lively carboation, butter finish.

33 cl. bottle @ home, bought @ Hogerdijk, Culemborg. Deep brown with a beige head. Malty aroma with caramel, molasses and berries. Not a standard dubbel at any rate because its too spicy, too fruity and not sweet enough but I like it nonetheless. Great, unusual, beer.

Pretty awesome appearance, cloudy chestnut with a beige head, just too bubbly and not creamy enough though. The nose is strawberries, Demerara sugar and cloves. Grrrrreat flavours of malts, brown sugar again, fruits, yes, an old barn full of ripe autumn fruits, and cross buns full of sweet spices. The flavour has a punch, a soft sourness that never gets on the way. Perfectly balanced. One of those irritatingly perfect little Belgian beers.

Dark cola color.
Sharp sour aromas...with a similar sweet&sour taste. 
A bit metallic aftertaste...

#346
Ein trübes braun mit reichlich Schaum. Ein Aroma nach Citrus, Minze und Koriander. Im Antrunk sensationell leicht und frisch. Geschmacklich eher dezent würzig und nicht so süß wie erwartet. Der lange Abgang klingt hefig und würzig aus (Nelke). Ein leckeres Grottenbier!
	
Test vom 26.3.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 9,11,11,12,11,11 - 10,95

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2013 Large frothy off-white head that mostly diminishes. Body is dark brown, cloudy and sparkling. Carbonation is soft and smooth. Aroma contains molasses, lemon, dough, banana and spices like cinnamon or speculaas. Flavor goes from acidic to sweet and malty, ending in light hoppy bitter. Palate is medium, with creamy texture. Its not very complex but its good. First time i drunk it acidity was too strong and present all the time which was a bit a let down. Perhaps it was the cold I had because the second time it was much better.
This is a pretty nice dubbel.  Medium bodied, dark amber brown color was nice head.  Aroma of spice and roasted grains, some vanilla, some brown sugar.
Scura, maltata, leggero torrefatto, terroso. Al palato molto equilibrata e pulita. Soddisfacente
Bonne brune qui se respecte. Elle a une entrée en bouche très correcte. Mais elle ne reste pas très longtemps en bouche.
Aparte dubbel, duidelijk anders van smaak dan de meeste. Mooie dikke schuimkraag zakt snel weg tot klein laagje. Frisse geur. Kruidig, ook van smaak. Hint van fruit, banaan?

Pours a dark amber color with a khaki head. Heavy nutmeg and cinnamon notes to this. A ton of spice notes alongside a fair amount of toffee and toasted malt. Hints of dark fruits on the finish. Quite spicy on the palate as well. Clove, nutmeg, and cinnamon flavors work nicely with the sweet dark fruits. Some toffee and toasted malt sweetness and a hint of chocolate.
Very creamy and round, very soft in the mouth, but less predictable as many other dubbels, less sweet. Long aftertaste, spices, clove I think?

Rich, spicy aroma with allspice and general christmas spice notes.

Clear and brown with a long lasting, slightly frothy head.

Taste follows aroma with a balance of sweetness and bittering and a nice spicy tang.

11/IX/2012 33cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker) @ home - BB: 18/XII/14 (2012-1017) 
Clear dark red brown beer, some beige to brown sediment floating around under a big creamy off-white to light beige head, pretty stable and adhesive. Aroma: grassy hops, pretty dusty, dry, some flowers, bit of citrus, hint of dried fruits. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: some citrus, bitter grassy hops, carbon sour, little malty, some grains. Aftertaste: grassy, citrus, pretty bitter hops, hint of dried fruits and caramel, if only very little. Dry bitter ending.
On tap at the porterHouse Central in Temple Bar Dublin. Nice Brown ale. Aroma is of sweetness, fruits (dark) and bananas.
33 cL bottle at Cafe de la Paix in Poperinge.  Dark brown with red highlights and a fair head.  Nice spiced aroma.  Pleasant, spiced, plenty of body, light.  In own goblet glass.

The head is ok, the body brown. It smells fruity a bit citrus a bit apple, alcoholic-plum. The taste is alcoholic, warmy, fruity, plum a bit raisin. full bodied fruity. The aftertaste is also fruity a bit bitter-plum. 11/12/11/11/11/11

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 33cl bottle from Cellier des Arcades, Arras. Pours a hazy brown with a small beige head. From my notes: satisfying smooth brown flemish ale, nutty, floral, caramel cake, good over-all. A good one to unwind with at the end of the day, but still worthy of contemplation.

0,33l bottle 6,5 ABV. Pours brown murky with creamy off-white lacing head. Aroma is licorice, raw cacao beans, malts, berries. Palate is slick soft, carbonation flat and smooth. Taste is roasted maltiness, some fruits, dry grassy spices, vague hoppy bitterness. Finish is soapy, dry bitter with  some berry notes, blackcurrant. Overall smooth and balanced Belgian Dubbel. Highly drinkable, although not really complex.

Bottle at home. 
White foam small bubbles. Dark amber color with brown notes. 
Spicy aroma with notes of apricot  and plumbs. 
Really nice felling in the mouth, small fine prickly bubbles. 
Taste of malt, pepper , cherry ?
Spicy aftertast, really nice. 
These Belgian brewers know their stuff !!

Bolton Brew Rocks !!

(bottle) pours a hazy dark ruby colour with a frothy off-white head. spicy aroma of herbal hops, marzipan and cherries, slightly leathery, with a hint of vanilla, and peaches. flavour is mostly bubble-gum and caramel, with a hint of barnyard and grain. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.

Hazy dark brown colour with a tan head. Yeasty, malty and light fruity aroma. A bit sour, but a fine caramel sweetness goes with it. Light fruity and some raisins. Soft texture.[Bottle. Trade with Grima]

18-AUG-2012, bottle @home, brought by Morten.
Hazy brown with high tan head.
Spice, malt, fruit, yeast, caramel, brown sugar.
Very high carbonation. Typical bruin and one of the good ones.Very tastefull.

Aroma: Smelling of yeast, vinegar and spices. Clove.Appearance: A clouded reddish brown beer, an off-white head with little lacing and small curtains.Taste: Starts with sweet bread, raisins, bitter oranges and some yeast.Palate: Medium low carbonation, soft texture, medium body.Overall: A nice sourish brew. Should be good with cave matured cheese.Note: Bottle 330 ml, thx KM. Reviewed 2012-08-25.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Aroma is pleasant although I cant say exactly what it is - something ale-yeasty, seems like an oaken or wooden, a bit alco. Color - hazy-brown with tones of deep-red,  nice, frothy foam. Taste - sweet with light bitter and light sour, a bit spicy. Body and texture - medium with soft carbonation, afterpath mild astringent. Not so sweet flavor as in St. Bernardus Prior 8 and some wooden aged tones, no hops at any aspect Good one.

750 ml bottle thanks to Dallas. Pours a deep murky brown color with a small tan head. A rich sugary and nutty nose. The flavor is a somewhat unusual Dubbel with brown ale elements, very dry, very mellow, dried fruits, toffee, earthy malts. Good.
Cerveza envejecida en cuevas. Tiene un aroma afrutado y un sabor excelente. Muy buena!

750ml bottle shared by Dallas 
Appearance: Cloudy brown with floating particles, medium sized off-white and good lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts and sweet toffee 
Taste: Sweet toffee and dark fruit 
Decent
Poured from a 750 ml bottle. Notes of caramel, peach, slight tartness, brown sugar, hints of spice. Very tasty.

Bottle. Pours a nice clear red brown, with a thick, creamy head. Aroma is yeast, kandi sugar, leather, dates and dark fruits and some rather strange herby notes of burned liquorice or anise. Medium body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is sweet, with notes of dark fruit, caramel and dark syrup. Massive, yet balanced and non-aggressive. A very drinkable beer.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours brown with good beige head. Aroma is of sweetness, fruits (dark), bananas. Taste is sweet, fruits, sligth acidity. Palate is ligth, refreshing. Overall: pretty interesting beer. Heavy belgian aroma/taste while being ligth and refreshing.

Bottle (750 ml). Thanks to minderbinder for sharing this one! Brown with a small beige head and some lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, spices and candy sugar. Taste is sweet with spices and fruits but less complex than aroma. Mouthfeel is dry and a bit watery. Thin body. Boring...

33cL bottle.  I like it, but I WANT to love it.  Its a beautiful rich mahogany color with a perfect small head, little lacing, and a translucent complexion.  It smells great, I cant pick out the individual smells, but its kind of complex.  The taste is also complex, certainly aging seems like a good idea, and although I like the finished product, I dont know that its my favorite from St. Bernardus.  Ive come to expect great beers from them, and this one is mediocre by their standards (but awesome for everyone else).
330ml bottle. Murky and muddy brown colour with a spray of light brown foam. Aroma carries lots of spice and a hint of sweetness. This is a full flavoured and easy drinking beer

Bottle @ t Antwaerps Bierhuiske. Cloudy dark brown appearance with a light brown head. Quite spicy, nutmeg/cinnamon, gingerbread cookie, slightly nutty, brown sugar aroma. Somewhat herbal/minty, light juniper, dark fruity, chewy/toasty malty flavor. Interesting stuff.
Colore bruno con schiuma beige persisitente. Al naso molto cioccolatosa e anche in bocca la parte dolciastra è in evidenza.

Cloudy brown/red with slightly beige foam. 
A nose of hops, spices and a touch of sweetness.
The taste is mostly refreshing (especially at the recommended serving temperature of 6-10°C) but relatively strong. Spices and surprisingly also some alcohol (perhaps reinforced by those spices), lively carbonation. Its rather a strong than a full taste, almost sour due to the spices. Aftertaste is slightly grapefruit-like bitter (mind you, not fruity at all) but again mostly those spices, reminds me of coriander amongst others. Not really my thing but thats personal, should make a fine choice for fans of the genre.

(Bottle; BBD: May 6th 2014) Pours a clear dark copper with medium, white head. Good lacework and retention. Aroma is malty with cherry-like notes and a hint of dust(!) Oily texture, soft carbonation, medium body and a sweet finish. Taste is mostly sweet. Too sweet and spicy for my liking, really.
brown coloured body with a off white head a fruity hoppy malty aroma a spicy malty fruity little caramel taste with a spicy alcholic bitter finish

Pours a rusty brown with a light head. The nose is floral sweet tarts, it must have some natural wild fermentation. Smells of red fruit, grapples, and nutmeg. The pallet is a off dry flavor of sweet and sour (sweet tarts/bottle caps). Cherry, grape, and red delicious apples. Very lite body, even a bit watery. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I found very hard to review this bier. Probably it was the high temperature of the beer when it was poured in goblet glass (perhaps it would be better a trappist glass, my bad).

So, making these remarks I saw a dark brown beer with brown 2-finger foam. When it went down it remained few lacings on the glass.

It didnt  smell a remarkable aroma for me (I blame the temperature, but Im not sure). Some spicy and yeast. And there was something that I just couldnt identify.

It tastes cherry syrup, no doubt. It starts sweet and goes towards dry bitterness. It is a very strange direction, full of curves. The high carbonation is so present that makes up the whole with some spicy flavor, yeast and apples.

Good dark belgian ale, but is seems to play around with us. Ill try it again to define better my opinion about it.

Dirty brown with a small pale head that leaves behind some lacing. Aroma is quite unexpected - sour candy, banana bread, barnyard, violets, hint of heather honey. Surprisingly light on the palate with a floral finish and a hint of bitterness. Taste is lavender, camomile, honey, candi sugar, violets, hint of citrus. Unique.

Bottle at Cambrinus in Brugge. 

Pours a hazy deep brown color with a medium sized head and good lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is floral and malty, lightly dusty, sweet smelling but somehow not sugary. 

The flavor is lightly spicy and there is a really interesting earthy hop profile that is surprisingly evident throughout despite the beer not really being particularly bitter. The beer has a mild toasty malt character & a good bit of chocolate.

Complex and tasty.
330ml bottle at 6.5%.  Pours a hazy dark caramel with a medium, frothy head.  Aroma is banana cake and bready malt.  Taste is bready to start.  Spicy artificial banana in the finish.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours an hazy brown with a nice beige head, aroma of cherries, sweet spices like clove, flavor is malty with nutmeg, dark bread, mint, nice carbonation, medium bodied

Somne head, not lasting, deep redbrown colour. Nose with brown sugar, sugar and fruit cake. Medium body with semi long length. Taste is also brown and white sugar and fruitcake. Really nice but also high carbonated.

Color marron oscuro con una pequeña espuma blanca que acompaña hasta el final.Carbonatacion media. Aroma a maltas caramelizadas, frutas, frutos secos. Sabor a maltas dulces, ligeramente afrutada con un final poco seco y dulce. El alcohol eata perfectamente escondido y apenas se nota.

Pours a dark brown colour with a fizzy white head. Aroma is sweet malt, yeast with some fruits and spices. Taste is also sweet malt, yeast, fruits and some spices leading to a fruity and yeasty finish with a light bitterness. Quite carbonated. Pretty decent.
Midbrown with fluffy white head and amazing fruit, spicy banana, Toffee Apple aroma. Sweet caramel, lovely carbonation, banoffee, plenty of yeast character.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours dark brown and cloudy, off-white head. Sweet spicy aroma - clove and nutmeg, Mildly sweet and spicy taste, a little anise. Heavy-medium body, lively carbonation, long, tangy finish. Decent.

Very dark brown-color with a nice 2 finger foam. Aroma has hints of sweet cherries. Same goes for the taste. Very sweet and unexpected from the appearance. The creator of white beer does it again! Damn good beer!

Brown 33cl bottle, best before May 2009, drank early, in July 2007. 

Poured into a forbidden fruit chalice. 

Looks cloudy, moody and interesting, I thought I had kept the gist out of the glass but obviously failed . Maroon red in colour, with a tight foaming, slightly off-white head. 

Grainy smell with yeast and malts too. 

Tastes strange, a mix of fruits which have gone off, not citrus fruits, but sour plums, pears and apples. Add hops to the mix and some breadcrumbs and you are halfway to getting the taste. 

Feels a little gritty in the mouth and the sourness lingers for a long time. 

Although I found the beer interesting, I cant say it will ever be a favourite. 

As a footnote, I purchased this bottle in Aubel on my way to the caves (Grotten) in Valkenburg, which is one of the towns the beer celebrates.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Brown-colored with a medium beige head. Aroma of fruit esters, bubblegum, licorice and spiciness. Sweetish flavor, malty and fruity, with caramel, sweet spiciness and a slightly drier finish. Medium-bodied. Pretty mellow, quite OK.

Bottle. Murky brown with a white head. Enticing nose. Aroma of sweet candy banana and clove. Well carbonated. Delicious flavor. Belgian yeast obvs, sweet candy, banana, clove, toffee and perhaps a quarter pinch of aniseed. Wonderful altogether.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2012 Pours a deep hazy reddish brown. Flavour of cherries, dried fruits and a little caramel, belgian yeasts and malts also evident. Decent head and decent long lasting carbonation, good full palate. Not much bitterness, just pleasant fruity belgian ale, nothing unusual, just very good stuff.

From bottle at the Cardinal stand, Stavanger Øl- og akevittmesse. Misty hazelnut body with a short lived, light brown film. Wooden cupboard and caramel on the nose. Sweet, spicy, light bitter flavors. Medium to full bodied. Grows in the mouth.
From the tap. Nice brown colour with humble head, never seen anything like it. Nice bitter afteraste. Pancakes with dark fruits, very enjoyable.
Tap. Pours dark brown with a high head. Like a spicy easter beer. Aroma belgian hops, spices. Medium palate. Not Bad.

Clear reddish brown colour, beige head. Yeast depot at the end. Aroma of banana, gumballs, yeast and toffee. Sweet malty flavour, caramel, light spices. Finish banana, roasted malts, light spiciness.
From 33cL bottle @ home)

on tap at the Doerak, Delft.
Thick off white head.  Ruby clear pour.  Nice aftertaste

Poured light brown with a decent but collapsing heat. The aroma was rich malts and a touch of cherry and some alcohol. The initial flavour was a little metalic but the richness of the malts shone through with some notes of fig and rich dark fruit. The body of this beer I found was a little on the thin side but still quite pleasant to sip on.

Bière de petit niveau alcoolique, surtout pour la brasserie Saint Bernard.
Couleur plutôt de vieille brune, dite en flamand, oude bruin.
Arômes de réglisse, sureau, pruneau frais, et une pointe de poivre noir.
La mousse tombe très vite.
La texture est plutôt liquide, rien dexceptionnel.
La première bouche est sur lépice douce, le piment léger, le blé noir et
lavoine. 
La seconde bouche révèle lamertume et le petit côté "oude bruin".
La troisième est assez piquante, avec un côté artisanal (les grottes?)
sans grande amplitude.
La finale ne révèle rien de plus.
Bière de niveau très moyen, largement surcotée sur notre site...
"Une fois nest pas coutume", dit le dicton.

330 ml bottle (label states 6.5% ABV). Pours murky dark brown with a small off white head. I get strong over-ripened bananas on the nose with a touch of spicy hops. Taste is sweet but dry with a candy sugar finish. Quite light bodied for the ABV. A good Bruin.
Hazy brown colour. Yeasty earthy aroma. Flavour is complex, fruity, caramel, with hints of brett. Nice

[ASPETTO] 			
marrone castagna, velata			
[SCHIUMA]			
beige, buona presenza, abbastanza fine e buona tenuta			
[OLFATTO]			
media intensità, lieviti, note tostate e frutta rossa, sentori alcolici			
[GUSTO]			
buona intensità, con primi sapori di malto, un leggero dolce e lieviti; vira velocemente verso note tostate, che ricordano vagamente caffè ma ancor più cioccolato al latte. Compare nel mezzo un fruttato vago, una punta astringente che si collega con un finale amaro, piuttosto deciso, che sembra provenire più che altro dalla tostatura dei malti. retrogusto secco, quasi speziato con un contributo alcolico controllato ma evidente .			
[TEXTURE]			
corpo medio, vellutata in bocca, una carbonazione inziale piuttosto elevata e pungente.			
[COMMENTO FINALE]			
sicuramente suggestivo deve essere bere questa birra in loco, nella grotta dove viene prodotta. Io mi accontento del soggiorno di casa mia. Forse  me la sono servita un po troppo fredda per cui i primi sorsi sono risultati un po penalizzati. contribuisce comunue anche una carbonazione pungente e sostenuta che copre inizialmente i sapori. laciando scaldare ed evaporare un po di Co2 , i malti cominciano a prendere corpo con un contrasto ben giocato fra note dolci e  amari; tostatura che poi prende il sopravvento in un quadro arricchito da note fruttate  e aromi speziati e alcolci , evidenti soprattutto nel finale. una oud bruin  interessante, da riprovare per coglierne maggiormente le sfumature.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2014 Cloudy brown with heavy white collar. Smells like an a old attic. Tastes a bit sweet, mandarin or orange taste at some point. But basically a bit acid. Taste of strong beer but feels mild. Sticky mouth.

Bottle; Pour is murky dark brown / amber with a frothy khaki head in this tulip; some nice lacing... average retention I suppose. I was thinking the nose was the highlight on this one, opposite of a recent rate. Caramel and toffee , mild fruity tones, and some brown sugar that provide a nice feeling. This one seems a bit over carbonated; it is perhaps lighter bodied than Id prefer. There are some candied sugars here... more fruits, caramel, breads, grass.... and some bitterness at the finish. I think it goes a bit downhill. A nice drinker... but lacking in the body I think would make it nicer.
Wow! This beer saved my Friday. An absolute delight. Will definitely buy another one. Smooth but tasty.

The aroma of this beer is nothing to get excited about. Its damp and grassy and if youd brewed this youd think at first whiff that youve done something wrong... Until you tasted it. It tastes great. Its peppery and sweet at the same time. Definitely better on the tongue than on the nose

Bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger.ABV 6,5. Pours cloudy dark brown with a huge creamy off-white head. Aroma of cellar,oak and spices. Taste is lots of spicy malts, oak with some earthy notes and belgian yeast. Lingering caramel finish. Very good and different Dubbel.

33cl bottle. Poured a dark brown beer with good formation of light beige head and with good lasting. Aroma is toasty, moderate yeasty, spicy and slightly caramelized. Flavour is spicy, to brown sugar, dried fruits, also some traces of cherries could be present, with a sweet and caramelized final of an average duration. Carbonation is lively. Body is high.
Bottle, pours hazy brown/red with medium head. Aroma is dark fruits, yeast, brown sugar. Taste is sweet with cherries, dark fruits, yeast, some bread. Medium mouthfeel. Nice
Servert fra flaske på Den Tatoverede Enke, København 5 Nov 11. Dyp amber/sort. Lavt skum. Syrlig fruktig aroma. Smaken er søt. Bare søt.

33cl bottle. Poured a dark brown beer with good formation of light beige head and with good lasting. Aroma is toasty, moderate yeasty, spicy and slightly caramelized. Flavour is spicy, to brown sugar, dried fruits, also some traces of cherries could be present, with a sweet and caramelized final of an average duration. Carbonation is lively. Body is high.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2013 33cl bottle. Hazy dark red/brown with a small dirty head. 
NOSE : Complex fuity aromas of cherry, pear, banana. Toffee and caramel. Clove. Dairy.
SIP : Smooth, full bodied with a good carbonation. Medium
sweet start with dried fruit flavored background. Gets a bit dry like clove. Spiciness leaves earthy residue on the tongue. Well balanced hop floral and malt aromas. Moderate bitter on the end.
OVERALL : its a refreshing beer for a dubbel but still complex and tasty.

(Courtoisie de rodenbach99)  Un anneau de mousse flotte sur un liquide à la robe brune.  De doux parfums fruités se choquent à des céréales caramélisées et à de fines épices.  Lalcool est bien caché.  Les saveurs sont correctes avec des malts et une levure qui portent avec simplicité lhabituelle signature des doubles.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps davantage moyen que faible avec une effervescence qui répond au style et une texture bien crémeuse.  La finale est doucement fruitée et secouée par des notes amères bien timides.
Very dark red body with a foamy off white head. Malty aroma with melon, caramel, some sourness. Sweet flavour with melon and brown sugar. A decent dubbel.

Bouteille de 750ml. Bouchon de liège, version à 6,5%. Bière brune avec une mousse beige, il y a une forte carbonation. Elle mousse beaucoup. Le nez est bien complexe avec des épices, des noisettes et du chocolat. La bouche offre des saveurs de noisette, dépices, de chocolat, elle est piquante et elle prend beaucoup dexpansion en bouche par le surplus de gaz carbonique. 7/10
Brown coloured beer with small off-white head and only few carbonation. Fruity malty aroma with some sweet hints. Full sparkling palate. Finish is sweet malty, soft finish slightly dry ending.
Cremosa al paladar con cuerpo, aromas a caramelo y mantequilla. sabor dulzon a levadura con notas amargas, buena abbey!
Bottle in Toronto. A nice sweet dubbel. Dark brown, dried fruit, caramel. Excellent spicy mouthfeel.

Strong alcohol aroma with raisins and plums notes. Gives a brownish hazy color with orange highlights, no foam unless a little brownish lace. Strong raisins flavor with fusel alcohols lght chocolate hints and nuts. Makes a interesting belgian dubbel but with no foam and a lack of maltiness. Little notes of oxidation after warming.

Bottle 750ml from Plonk. Great beer, very yeasty. Aromas of grain, butter, and burnt caramel. Taste is sweet, with sour and bitter notes, and very long length. Palate is creamy, and full bodied. Cloudy brown, with a frothy head.

On tap at the Cafe Belgique in Amsterdam. Pours dark brown with a creamy, off-white head. Dark malts, dark fruits, grapes, fruit punch and berries make up the aroma. Quite a sweet flavor, more dark fruits, light chocolate, almost licorice notes, sherry, some floral notes. Medium to full in body with average but heavy carbonation. Lightly warming finish, tingly carbonation here and some booze, sweet and fruity, florals on the tail, some burnt candi. Pretty decent brew.

0,75 l. bottle from the supermarket. Corked bottle - always festive when the cork pops off. Dark brown colour with ruby hues, creamy light brown head, that settles fast. Malty, roasted aroma with notes of grains, dark fruits, prunes and chocolate - I am thinking Danish brown christmas cookies! Lots of yeasts here, as usal in good Belgians. Sweet taste with lots of malts.  A little to bit sweet for my tastebuds, but still a well made beer with lots of body, and a long lasting finish.
Bottle @ Cafe Buitenlust, Oirschot. Dark amber color, average off-white head. Decent smell, nice taste, average carbo and body. Useful beer.

33 cl bottle. BBE 24.09.2012.

The front of his bottle poured clear brown, though the nearer we got to his bottom, the bottle-conditioned sediment turned clear dark browns into a soft, slightly milky dark brown. He tasted darn good both ways though. Let me explain. Atop his browns was a whitish head which lingered as a thin film sans lace. As much as I enjoy gazing upon a luxurious head marked by decorative lace, so too do I enjoy reveling in a bouquet of aromas rich with the spice of life. Brown sugar, cinnamon, toffee, caramel, candied apples, red licorice, raisin bread stuffed with plump dark raisins and sprinkled with allspice and everything nice. His nose plays with red and black plums soaked in old tawny port. Nice doesnt even come close to describing his nose, and without further ado, I dive into his awaiting depths. Being bottle-conditioned, his body and mouthfeel is frothy with bubbly effervescence which carries his rich palate across my tastebuds in ethereal fashion. Whereas the black and red plums steeped in port came last in his nose, they come first in his palate which is chewy with a healthy chunk of raisin bread fresh from the oven. I do love me some raisin bread, and Grotten Brown has plenty. Grapes flitter in and out of the plums, while their skins make for a tart bitter bite in the back of each swallow. He lightly dries the top of my tongue which is quite happy at the moment while I admire a healthy dose of chunky delights hovering suspended in his brown depths. Chunks are good, whether mixed in the beer or as a healthy shot of concentrated vitamin B at the end. The second half of his bottle changes character in a fascinatingly tasty way. Sweet maple melts into an ocean of toffee as apples bob up and down, desperately fighting a losing battle for air. Every now and then, I manage to steal a bite which is ripe with fresh apple juices and succulent meats. Id kiss him, if I could. Instead, Ill settle for finishing off the remains of our shared bottle which finishes with less effervescence for a smooth and slightly heavier mouthfeel which revels in plums, grapes, apricots, and a dash of vanilla extract.

Taste: If you drink this cold it comes off as a really watered down and boring brown. When cold it gave me the impression that this one doesnt age well and if you still have it, its probably past peak already. But as it warmed up I got more flavor out of it. Still not a fantastic brown by American standards, but a decent Belgian brown.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Slightly creamy due to the time allowed for the bottle conditioning to continue.

Drinkability: Simple flavors, not a heavy mouthfeel, and an abv below 7% so its pretty sessionable.

Serving type: bottle

Hazy grayish brown beer with a beige head. Sour and malty aroma and taste. You can definitely recognize this one as a Belgian even if you didn’t know it already.

(Bottle 75cl.) Pours beautifully reddish brown with a beige head. Complex malty and yeasty earthy aroma with a whiskey touch.  Flavour of caramel malt, yeast and dried fruits (Special B malt?) Bitter finish like juniper.

Bottle.  Nice beer! Brown pour, tan head.  Prunes, raisins, yeast, spice aroma.  Flavor is full of the prune and raisin flavors with some interesting tartness.  I liked it.  arrogantb is right, good food beer.

A friend was kind enough to share this with me. It had a cloudy yellow color that looked murky and the head was a white sticky pillow. The smell was musty and earthy to me. Bottled: Aroma is sourly/fruity, notes of plums, spices and herbs. Hazy, brown color, foamy off-white head. Fruity, sourly flavor. Notes of bananas, grapes, lemon peel, herbs and some alcohol. Notes of cinammon, cloves, herbal hops in the end. Dry, quite bitter end. Complex, tasty beer.

Bottle, mostly likely aged for a year or so.  Pours a cloudy brown with a thick off-white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, some light spices (pepper, allspice even) and a touch of roasted malt. 7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)

Bottle, not sure how old, but doubtful that its fresh based on the fact that it was the last bottle of it on a shelf of beers that clearly sees little action. 750ml bottle.  Pours a rocky, light-brown, lasting head with a slightly hazy, particulate laden, amber body.  Clumpy lacing. Medium bodied with a somewhat creamy texture and average carbonation.

Expired in 05/2008 and Im tasting it right now. Beautiful aroma, dark coloured appearance with a small white head. Very complex aroma and flavour. But lacks some body. Very good beer, never drank a fresh one. This is great stuff. (Bottle 33cl)

Chestnut brown beer with big beige head. Aroma is great and complex: malty sweetness, spicyness, anise, red currants, yeast. 330 ml bottle. 6.5%. Finland.
Brown colour with medium off-white head.
Sourish fruity aroma with some spices and hints of yeast and nutmeg. Fruity, malty and spicy flavour with some bitterness. Well carbonated.

330 ml bottle, 6,7%. Clear brown color, airy off-white head. Spicy aroma with alcohol. Fruity flavor with some medicinal alcohol. Medium-full body, very high carbonation, sharp mouthfeel. Gets better as it warms up, but it never got particularly good.

Bottle. Brown colour with a medium off-white head. Aroma of yeast, spices and malt. The flavour is dry, yeasty and malty with notes of spices, citrus and some dark fruits. Medium bodied and quite smooth mouthfeel. Very tasty.

Corked and caged.  Ruby pour with a hint of brown seeping in, patchy sudsy tan head.  Nose very airy with dusty yeast - malty, but theres not much here.  A little bit of kick in the taste, peppercorn in with vomity caramel and a little spice.  Herbal notes, dry aftertaste.  Seems like a hint of candi sugar under the light chocolate.  Medium body. Yeasty, citrusy-fruity aroma. Dryish, fruity, yeasty and spicy flavor. Palate is quite smooth.

330 ml bottle. Cloudy orange-brown colour, off-white head that leaves some lacing. Very pleasant fruity and spicy aroma, with some yeast and a whiff of alcohol. The flavour is rather dry, fruity and spicy, with some bitterness and alcohol warmth in the finish.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Good nose.  Kinda fruity, little funky, a bit spicy.  Flavor is similar but a little less than the nose.  Very creamy and excellent mouthfeel.  Dug it.

Doesnt smeel that good, and I think the taste starts out good but then gets a little cheap candy flavor. Sweet with a hint of red ale.

This intriguing cave-aged brew pours a light chestnut brown with ruddy highlights and a large puffy beige head which laces beautifully in sheets and rings around the glass. Certainly complex, the nose is strikingly nutty, coincidentally suggesting candied chestnuts (marrons glacés), walnuts and plenty of hazelnuts. Genuine vanilla bean is in ample supply and very attractively highlighted by browned butter and salted-butter caramel. Perhaps I was synesthetically influenced by the description, but the nose had a damp, almost mossy spice component. Spice cake, prunes, raspberries and black pepper also lend to the complexity. The flavor continues to suggest hazelnuts, though rye bread and heavy yeast aspects are also dominant. The mouthfeel is exceptionally silky, reminiscent of a good cappuccino. Dried fruits become increasingly intense as the beer warms. Particularly apparent are dried pears, apricots and figs, each lending a vinous tone to this fascinating brew. A subtle but enjoyable earthy sourness lingers with the remaining malt bitterness. Well balanced, this an exciting, unique and eminently drinkable beer. A delicate and thoughtful effort that ages well and obviously garners my respect for Pierre Celis. (24/06/07, best by 21/11/08)

I love the whole concept of cave beer; and this is certainly a bottle worth retreating to and finding solace in.

Tasted 12/05/2008. 330ml bottle courtesy of BozoNZ (I think it came from one of the Chch BJCP tastings, possibly via The Beer Emporium, RIP).  This sat around in the cellar for sometime but I neednt worry, best before is not until 2010. Pours a slighty fiery murky dark amber - this really looks like muddy homebrew, so top marks for not trying to be this years model.  Subtle but extraordinarily complex aroma features marmite at first, then an excellent mix of dark dried fruit (tending to prune) with a little baby sick and leather. Settles to a nice brett-like sourness with a light toast character and an excellent dry woody note. Caramel shows through as it warms.  In the mouth it is more of the same - all the complexities of the nose, which I would simplistically describe as woody, brett-infected, peppery cola (is it Coke or Pepsi?) with a dry leathery finish.  A little aniseed and earth enter the mix in the finish. Light mouthfeel, medium-full carbonation. Understated, sleek, simple, sublime, sexy. My style of beer, and one of the best. I want more.  Thanks Craig, just like this beer: youre a legend!

750mL, no date from TheCheeseMan and the Mystery Swap 3.0.  My label is colored differently and lists 6.7% ABV.  Clear reddish orange with a one finger off-white brownish head, good retention.  Aroma is quite figgy and raisiny up front with some brown sugar and yeasty spice.  It has a minerally background.  Flavor adds a hint of roast and grainy malts which helps pull back the reins on the sweetness I was getting in the aroma.  There is also a bit of mustiness (like from an old cork).  The finish is dry and slightly earthy, bitterness minimal.  My glass is left with a sheet of contrasting thicknesses of unbroken lace.  Moderate carbonation with a body thats a little too thin--maybe due to the lower alcohol?  A tasty dubbel--Id been contemplating getting this from the store down the street, but TheCheese made it so I didnt have to.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
(cleaning out my beer bottle collection as pictured in my profile and utilizing ratebeer.com)
As I recall, this was a very good abbey dubbel.  Unique blend of hops, fruits, and floral flavors.
Bottle at Belgo. You know, in London. I love how people assume we know where you drink. Caramel, toffee type thing going on. Nice dubbel, get the fuck in.
Bottle.  Sweet raisin malt aroma.  Medium brown with small head.  Brown sugar, raisin malt flavor with light alcohol burn to finish.
750 ml. bottle, raisin nose and brown color, slightly watery but a nice little hop and a good tasty dubbel
Draft at Toronado. Brown colored. Aroma is sugary with some darker malts, Belgian yeast, a touch of darker fruit. Too thin.

330ml bottle at the White Horse with tashi and renffisch, 23rd March 2008. Pours brown with a frothy head. Floral and citrus notes complement the caramel malt aroma. The flavour is very similar and the palate is reasonable. An interesting Bruin but nothing special.

22oz bottle from Total Wine, poured into a Duval glass. Murky light brown, I see a little yeast. Small fizzy head. Smell is candi sugar, raisin and caramel with a bit of funk. Taste it classic dubbel. Up front yeast, sugar, raisin and chocolate caramels, on the back end some hops and spice. A slight touch of sour cherry comes through as it warms. This is pretty complex for a dubbel. Well done beer.

It pours earthy amber with a coarse light beige head. The aroma is classic Belgian ale. Sweet caramel, dark candy sugar, dried prunes, infused with a peppery element. In the mouth, it starts mildly sweet with lots of caramel, spice and apricot fruitiness. As it moves around, the mouthfeel seems light with alcohol well hidden and a good amount of carbonation playing the tongue, finishing in mild dry streak.
Brown with a huge head. Spicy with notes of roasted malts, citrus, pepper and toffee.

Dark brown colored with red hints. Medium sized yellow head. Dominating spices in aroma with some cookies, hops, syrup and mild alcohol. Medium bodied. Flavor is not so sweet with spices and hops, some berry sourness also present. Carbonated palate. Aftertaste has also this ginger bready cookie tone with mild alcohol.

Pours a dark reddish brown color with a small to medium sized light brown head. Nose is sour, fruity, and somewhat alcoholic. Taste is a tad bitter, fruity, sweet, malty, and dry. Not a full of a taste as I usually would like but it is super smooth and has a very nice mouthfeel.

From thebelgianaleshop.com (european bottle version). Aroma is strong undercurrents of candi sugar, wet grass, caramel, plum. Flavor has the same qualities, complimented with a firm malt midsection. Im glad this isnt overdone with alcohol. So  much character here to ruin with an obscene amount of strength. A great beer, only wish I could have it aged.

Pour is a brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is yeast and spice with an intense candi sugar.  Flavor is again candi sugar but not to the extreme as in the aroma, also i get some molasses and caramel with a touch of dark fruit.  An above par example of the style and something you could sip on for a long afternoon sitting outside on a chilly night.

Bottle(6.7%) from BevMo. Pours a dark amber color with a moderate off-white head. Nose is somewhat spiced and sour. Very prickly carbonation. Some roasted dark fruitiness along with some spices. Some roasted malts as well.
750 I got in an inperson trade in texas.  Pours brown with a tan ring.  Nose is full of yeast and spice.  Taste is somewhat rich and sweet, a little eh for me, but not bad at all.

(bbe 24/12/07) Dark reddish brown, hazy, with lacy light beige head. Nose is a little sour with berries and exotic fruits, shows a really nice calvados aroma when it warmes up. Nicely hopped, even a bit Orval like. Flavor is dry and well hopped. Finishes with liquorice, spices and soft maltiness. Yeast softens things up, perhaps too much even. Medium bodied with strong foamy carbonation. Surprisingly refreshing.

Pours a dark golden brown to black with a thin filmy head. Caramel, chocolate, smoke, wheat bread, and candied malts in the aroma. Intensely sweet flavor at the tip of the tongue, like fruity candy followed by hearty wheat, with a smooth caramel finish. Palate is thin and watery and a little unbalanced.

Draught. Piercingly sweet artificial strawberry aroma. Dark ruby with white lacing from nearly no head. Fruity-sweet, nearly cloying and thin. Maybe a nice dessert beer, in small amounts, but otherwise not enjoyable.
Uni Staff Club Tasting 29/01/08. Murky brown, lively good head. Aroma reminescent of prunes with a touch of linament and perhaps sarsparella. Complex, sweet woody flavours, the odd spice note too

Labeled as Grotten Brown, at 6.7% abv. Aroma is moderately malty with a bit of grassy hops, light yeast and some corinander. Large, frothy, light brown head, which diminishes into white caps and a ring. Muddy, dark brown body. Taste is water and a bit bland for St. Bernardus. Yeasty and somewhat boring finish. Watery mouthfeel, lively carbonation, and a copper feel to the finish.

330 ml bottle @ Bishops Arms in Jonkoping, Sweden. 
Pours hazy brown deep red. Head is begie. It has a very beautiful appearance in the proper glass. Aroma is loaded with strawberry, sweet malt, rubber, caramel. It´s little winous but not sour. The mouthfeel is little bubbly and big. Taste is from burnt sugar, syrup, dark berrys and caramel malt. St. Bernard Brouwerij delivers another fine brew!!

brown burgundy color and medium fluffy head. toffee and spice bread aroma. surprisingly thin body. burnt sugar and maple maltiness with dark raisins and bready clove notes. it is a lot simpler than their other beers, its ok but the St. Bernardus beers are better

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2008 Heavy caramel and sugar aroma.  It has a sugary taste with some sweet malt and syrupy finish with a hint of cherry.  No lace present.  Very mellow beer.  I could drink a lot of this very complex beer.

0.25l Bottle. Blueberry, caramel, brown sugar and date aroma. Hazy red, off-white layer. Brown sugar edges, almond, the fruits to a lesser degree, somewhat dry, finishing on a metallic date-sweet note. Mellow, light sparkly mouthfeel.  Pleasant but not overwhelming.
Nice reddish browm color.  Creamy white head that was held for a while.  Nice malty (to me) aroma.  Slightly sour taste with a bitter finish.  Good, but Ive had better.
On tap at Maxs.  Dark brown with white head.  Chocolate malt aroma.  Slight citrusy sourness to start.  Gives way to bitter alcohol finish.  Wasnt a big fan of it.

Called Grotten Flemish Brown Cave Aged, on tap at Maxs Taphouse in Baltimore during Belgian fest.  Translucent, deep brown with a slim white head.  Fruity, slightly rummy, malty aroma.  Flavor is of dark fruit, plums, dark candy, grains,cheese and rather earthy.  Texture is creamy and a little chewy.  Cave aged?  I guess, but it was alright no matter where it was aged.

delicate and complex fruit nose, apples, sweet yeasts, pear, rich complicated flavor, lightly toasted apples and spices, mild malts and hints at bitters, smarties (like the parade candy), toffee and delicious spicey character, well done

The cork pops, and this much hyped beer pours into my Westmalle chalice a ruby, brown like color. It smells of yeast. 

I was at first extremely dissapointed by this beer, but as it warmed from cellar to room temperature, I discovered a much fuller flavor. This beer has dark fruit flavors aplenty. The finish is quite dry. 

I forgot to mention the wonderful head retention of this beer. I should also mention that I paid only $7.50 for this beer.

75 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a lacing tan head. Light yeast, caramel malt and slight woody aroma. Flavour is light acidic,woody, caramel malt with a very controlled sweetness and brett note. Complex fruity, malty and yeasty brew. Light note of dried fruit. Lingering caramel malt and yeasty finish.

Pours an opaque Brownih color with a thin tan bubblie head. Aroma is woody and spicy. Taste of coriander and carbinated Almost an overpowering spice taste. 
St. Bernard is one of my favorites...this is not.

Having this one on draft at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin. Poured with and nice head with plenty of lace. Brownish color with some amber and cherry highlights. Malty body but not too thick. Some sweet/tartness. Dark fruits, toffee, and some yeasty flavors predominate. Very nice. Good finish.

Fresh 750 ml first pour in Gulden Draak tulip.  Reddish brown with lasting tannish head and lace.  Freshly turned earth and wood aroma with mild cinnamon bubble gum.  Earthy caramel brown sugar and wood flavor with very mild raisin fruitiness and mild tobacco bitterness in finish.  Medium body and carbo.  Very nicely complex, amazingly refreshing and palatable.   Im blown away.  I guess I wasnt expecting much, not sure why.  This is delicious.

750 Ml Bottle-Pours a cloudy brown color w/a slight head & good lacing. Sweet, fresh, Belgian aroma. Great fresh Belgian flavor of cane sugar, bread dough, yeast, dark fruit, & a touch of peat. Has a little spice to it. This was quite good, but that shouldnt be a surprise from this brewer. Had never heard of it when I saw it in the store but bought it as soon as I saw St. Bernard on the label. Good stuff.

Bottle @ MicroBar, Clapham Nov07. Murky reddish / brown pour. Aroma is vinous . dark fruits / chocolate / raisins. Taste is dark fruits / much the same as aroma really although doesnt deliver that knockout blow on drinking.

75 cl. bottle pours a massive head if yer not careful. Dark, ruby- brown color. Has a subtle bread and butter smell. Very nice smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Pretty mild flavor of nine grain bread with a mild, citrusy hop bite to finish. A well balanced brew, but too mild in the flavor department.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 0.33 l bottle. Slightly hazy reddish brown color with thick head. Fruity, perfumed and toffeish aroma with notes of vanilla and alcohol. Toffeish, caramelly and yeasty flavor with dry woody spiciness. Dry spicy bitter finish. Kind of muddy.

Draught. Pours dark brown/black with a moderate off-white head. Aroma is toffee, Belgian-style yeast, and a hint of spice. Flavor is moderately sweet toffee malt, rather like a brown ale with a bit more complexity and the distinctive Belgian yeast character---maybe a Belgian analog to an Old Ale. Pretty good.

Semi-opaque brown with a speckled tan head. Metallic hop smell within a fizzy effervescent fog of indistinct aroma. Taste is dry with a cidery edge and light tartness that attends such high carbonation.  Finishes cleanly with a residual tingle on the tongue

opaque brown body with avey nice thick white head. There is quite a bit of citrus-lemon and lime. There is also a yeast smell and a little bit of a root beer aroma. The flavor is actually pretty light with some nutty flavors and some cinnamon. This is pretty dry tasting but has a bit of a lingering sweetness- strange.
Mmmm YUMMY! On tap at the BURPCASTLE! Tasty chocolate mocha! Deep brown and fizz-ay! MM!

Ruby red when held to light, with a soft head that leaves a ring around glass and a spotty lacing. Immediate smell of iron with smells of bread and a slight hint of plum is hidden in there as well. Yeasty, a bit of iron, nuts, clove, dark fruit, and toffee in the taste. Light on the tongue, medium body and medium carbonation. It was an alright beer, but I dont think Ill be buying this again.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with a tight, very small head.  Aroma is candi sugar and fruity yeast.  Starts off fruity, moves on to a little bit of wood with a little sourness.  Finishes with a bready/cinnamony astringency.
I had this beer once and thought it was the best. I had it at Eulogy in Philadelphia. Its a great beer to have in the winter with a bowl of mussells. Get busy living or get busy dying.

Pours a fine head that falls into a thin layer with a very strong lacing made of millions of tiny bubbles that look pillowy. So many smells hit my palate from metalic to sweet smells. The taste and smell of the hops is very suttle, but it creates a little different flavor. Mouthfeel is very carbonated and a little smooth. Its very watery on the tongue. The more and more you drink this beer, the less flavor and body there is.

As Pierre Celis Signature collection. Clear reddish brown, big rocky beige head. Nice tart and mildly fruity aroma. Firat flavors are tart, as well, with some earthy, woodsy bnotes. Nice sweet finish, with some sour notes.

had at the Flying Saucer, Houston :::: Lacing is magnificent! lots of belgian yeast and overripe fruits .. better than expected! .. a nice smooth belgian that went very well with a fine cheese platter! ..

Bottle. Tremendous brilliant pop from the cork. Body-dark honey with a quarter inch foamy head. Nose-candi sugar, brown sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, bready, light metal. Taste-light perfume, bready like a sourdough starter, light sweetens, sour on the back end, the unsweet portion of caramel, mostly dry, lightly woody, astringent on the tip of my tongue, some white spices, sharp and almost stinging (but not too much) CO2, light banana, creamy mouthfeel. A very subdued drinkable beer. I like the way the spices play out.

Bottle at Microbar, Clapham. Dry fruits and dates detected in the nose. Murky red and brown. Small head. Sprinkle of small carbonated ribbons. Soft mouth feel. Vinegar, sweet alcohol. Not bad a bit on astringent and chalky. One of the best looking beers out there but taste doesnt quite match the looks.

Pours a very dark and opaque brown into the glass with a thick tan head.  Sweet malty/caramel flavor.  Delicious.

On tap.

Bottle. Poured dark bronze. Took a while to tell that given its nearly entirely head. Foamy, but quick dissipating. Good lacing. Yeasty aroma with sour citrusy notes. Taste is more of same. This tastes like it will get old quickly (like, by the end of the bottle), but it is interesting.

Bottled, at least a few years old.  Poured clear, deep garnet with a delightful creamy cap of beige head that stayed til the end.  The aroma picked up a nice, dry, spicy yeast strain with some white pepper, light fruits, and some piney notes.. soft, a touch sour, and very well-composed.  The flavor didnt dissapoint.. chocolate and aged caramel at the mildly sour core with darker fruit skins, pepper, and crusty bread riding the edges.. mild fruity bitterness.  Just shy of medium-bodied with a nice sweet/sour contrast throughout.. dry and refreshing on the palate.  Great beer!
Draft: Reddish brown, aroma of burnt caramel, I couldnt pick up much flavor, kinda bland.
Dark ruby brown with a fluffy white head.  Yeasty vinous aroma.  Sweet caramel flavor.  Light and spritzy.

25/10 0.33 l bottle at Hopdevil. Poured dark reddish brown colored body with big brownish head. Aroma is a sourish with caramel and fruity, primarily orange, then also some dark tropical fruits. Flavor is better, quite full and fruity as well. Chocolate felt inside, caramel also. Aftertaste is short, sweetish, very pleasant with oily texture both in the glass and on palate. Very nice beer, thanks Petra for choosing this one as well.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2008 (tap) A totally unique beer that impressed me. Aromas and flavors of tropical fruits. Pithy and dense. Some sourness, must, and spice. I would like to have this again.
 re-rate (bottle--red label but is the brown for sure). Impressed me again. A subtle, understated beer that can easily be overlooked and under-appreciated and apparently is. Complex flavors include smoked apple, applewood-smoked bacon, and a smidgen of licorice. Dry finish. Mouthfeel is chewy, smooth, light. Nose is apple & pear, guava & lemon, on one layer--and another layer of earth and wood. I could make this a daily beer, easily.
pretty carbonated - very dark - loaded with spices and pretty woody.  I like it caved!  Very good beer - of course from the maker of St. Bernardus

BB date 01/03/03...damn. another gift from a clients wine cellar. hazy brown with orange hints and a fluffy cream colored head with HUGE bubbles. this really wanted out of the bottle! aromas of caramel, wood barrels, cinnamon and orange. medium mouth feel with lots of carbonation. flavor is funk, earth, floral yeast, toffee and a dried herb/spice that i cant place.theres definitely some oxidation and a slight sourness that keeps me coming back. so much going on that im a bit overwhelmed. ill have to taste it fresh and rerate because THIS bottle is smarter than me...
Hazy brown with medium head. Aroma has yeast, fruits and spices. Same goes for the flavor with a bitter end. I dont get this one.

Bottle, 33cl.  Dark red brown color, with large off-white head. Aroma plummy, with bit roasted malts, little spices. Taste malty, dark fruits bit yeast, complex and nice. 
Very good.
750 ml bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar.  Brown amber with a foamy white head.  Dried fruit and yeast aroma.  Earthy and fruity taste with a slight spice and oaky notes with a semi-sweet finish.

Bière brune ambrée, voilée avec des pellicules de levures. Col très mince et éphémère de teinte crème.
Parfum léger de malt, de caramel et de réglisse.
Ces saveurs se retrouvent en bouche, avec une note liquoreuse et dalcool agréable.
Très pétillante et rafraîchissante.
Savoureuse!
WBF. Pours a hazy brown with a medium tan head. The aroma is musty, sweet, spicy. The flavor is musty and sweet as well. Slight sour. Caramel.
330ml bottle. Cloudy brown colour with a decent tan head. Aroma of caramel and dark fruit. Flavour of toffee with some spice and a slightly sweet finish. Good.

750 ml bottle labeled as the Pierre Celis Signature Selection - no mention of caves. Aroma of yeast spice, light fruit, dark fruit, arguably citrus. Ruby color with a beige head that was vigorous and persisting. Kept climbing out of the bottle neck. Medium bodied; creamy carbonation. Dark fruit, touch of heat, wood, roasted malt. Very nice feel in the mouth. The finish is pretty dry, seems to have a citrus touch, leaves wood notes. Malt is noticeable, but its not a sweet ending. It is a great ending.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Appealing deep copper, small yeast flecks and a tight tan head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of big, chewy malts - caramel, toffee, treacle; raisins, figs, fruits; slightly herbal with definite warm spices, all balanced by some acidity and slight citrus zing. 
  
Palate:  Medium body, smooth, soft carbonation, a touch syrupy.
  
Flav.:  Woody and tangy, vinous, the sweet, chewy malts are more in the background than they were on the nose, some of the spices and herbs come through; a touch sweet and a little thin at the end; leaves a pleasant light toasted malt finish that is a bit vinous.

Not huge and cavernous, but certainly welcome in my grotto.

Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before 12 01 10, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on September 30 2007; eye: caramel, lightly hazy, slight effervescence, nice creamy beige head, lacing; nose: yeast, spices, banana, light fruitiness from small dark berries, malt, caramel; mouth: soft, creamy, good balance of malt and caramel, a little wave of banana, spices, a hint of alcohol, finale in malt-caramel with a good presence of yeast, mildly sweet, medium body, quite carbonated; overall: very good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, meilleure avant 12 01 10, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 30 septembre 2007; il : caramel, légèrement voilée, très légère effervescence, belle mousse beige crémeuse, dentelle; nez : levure, épices, banane, léger  fruitée de petits fruits noirs, malt, caramel; bouche : doux, crémeux, bon mélange de malt et de caramel, petite vague de banane, épices, une trace dalcool, finale en malt-caramel avec une bonne présence de levure, moyennement sucrée, corps moyen, assez carbonatée; en résumé : très bonne

Wow! This tasted like a mix between a dubbel and a Flemish sour. I know it sounds wierd but what a unique taste. Pour was a dark brown with a huge pillowy 3 finger tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and alcohol. Taste was first sweet, then sour with hints of dark cherry, yeast and citrus. Nice big carbonation. As it warms, the beer bites the gums and the constant battle of sweet and sour rage on to your delight. Im glad I picked this up.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: A dark hazy brown ale with a thick big bubbled light moka head, with small dark floaties. The aroma is nice, veering on a light flemish sour, with light lemon, vinager, horseblanket. In mouth, a nice crisp malt, with light licorice and woody notes, prunes. A bit short in mouth, but very well done. Bieropholie import. BB15/12/06.

Draft under the label Pierre Celis Signature Collection Grotten Belgian Ale: Coffee and raisin aroma. Clear brown with a thick tan head. Tastes of horehound, cherry, and hops, in good harmony. Wood and slight smoke on the palate. Rather nice.

Pours a dark, clear ruby with a nice tan head. Nose is sugary sweet and yeasty with a pungent tone to it overall. Flavor is smooth, woody and sweet. Low yeast flavor, but an underlying sweet tone that hits the tip of your tongue and never comes on strong at all. Wood-like aftertaste. Feel is a perfect balance of carbonation and use of ingredients. Overall a damn good brew. Even and well balanced and one I would constantly go back to time and time again.

Bottle, with Fin, Loz and Traci. Hazel brown, a bit of white head. Brown sugar aroma, a nice dose of overripe banana (usually not a fan of that smell in beer, but its done with a gentle touch here) tart cherries, milkshake, banilla. Bright fruit flavor, pepper, very spicy and bright, but some accompanying chocolate notes. A bit of round sourness. Thanks Fin!
Copper-red / brown colour, Large off-white head. Aroma is of sweet fruits and spices. Taste is of sweet malts and dried fruits, but is not very complex. However, pleasant to drink.

Purchased 750 ml from Holiday Wine cellar. The beer poured as a medium shade of brown with a huge eruption of foam overflowing from the glass. Has a fully delivery for an aroma that is decked with a large spice and yeast profile. A nice strong flavor of malt in balance with spice and true Belgian spice makes this worth the price in the end.

Flaske. Rigtig lækker dubbel. Meget drikbar men desværre mangler den en smule dybde, som evt. kunne være opnået med en lidt større alkoholmængde, men en super crossover øl.

6/30/07 On draught at the Seattle International Beerfest.  Aroma is an interesting blend of apricot, caramel and sweet malt.  Appearance is copper with an off-white head with good retention.  Flavor is sweet malt forward with light caramel and dried fruit.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a low carb feel.  Overall a very easy drinking sweet brew.

Bottle shared with Casey, Loz, Traci in a Belgian beer tasting night  Warm amber in colour, with sourish nose some spice? Tasred initially a tiny bit sour but sweet malty flavours coursed through, this reminded me of an ice lolly I had as a kid some sort of cider apple lolly as I recall Not that it particularly tasted of cider apples but then again nor did the lolly, but there were definate similarities a soft brown sugar finish with some dryness and I really rather enjoyed this suprise package.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2007 Bottiglia 33cl comprata a Brignole; piuttosto scura maron schiuma bianca tendente al beige. Aroma non molto, ma piacevole tra il dolce e lacidino. Sapore complesso e un filo erbaceo con finale amaro (luppoloso) e speziato; corpo pronunciato, quasi vischioso e molto frizzante. Una birra abbastanza particolare, che se la tira anche un po, ma  anche un poco faticosa da finire. ________________ENGLISH TEXT HERE__________________33cl bottle bought at a wine shop near Brignole; rather dark brown with white to beige head. Aroma is evanescent but pleasant, between sweet and sour. Flavor is complex and a bit herbal with bitter finish, hoppy and spicy; body is very pronounced, almost muddy and carbonation is high. A weird brew, with low drinkability.

Cloudy red-orange color with a full sticky head and some pretty heavy lacing. Appealing bubble gum and demerara sugar aroma. Lighter spicier notes might be phenols. Nice sugar and fruit up front on the tongue, with quite a bit of carbonation that lifts it right off the palate. Almost foamy mouthfeel, which has just a touch too much carbonic bite.  Semi-dry finish with a lingering spiciness and a hint of alcohol. Nice, with some good complexity, but could be more drinkable, especially at only 6.5%.

Bomber @ Publick House, Brookline, MA, shared with ArcaneApollo.  We were intrigued by the "cave-aged" description, and this beer did not disappoint.  Pours a wonderful deep brown with a medium-sized white head.  The aroma is candy sugar, with malt and slight fruit thrown in as well.  Taste is heavily malty; the cave environment definitely added to the complexity of the beer.  It is incredibly smooth on the palate, and you begin to notice fruit, spice, and hop notes toward the end.  Great beer.
POured deep brown with a white head.  Notes of sweet malt and molasses.  The flavor of hops touch nicely in the finish and the palate.
Deep cobber colour with a thick white head. Caramel, sweet malt and alcohol. Caramel and a bit of hops with alcohol warmth in the cheeks
750ml - Red brown body.  Fruity aroma with a light sweet flavor, with some spice.  Nice Dubbel.  Id like to age a bottle for future comparison.
750ml bottle. Tulip glass. Deep amber with a thin head. Aroma was sweet and spicey. Tasted of dark fruit, spices, caramel, hint of chocolate and perhaps licorace.
Bottle sampled. Pours brown with ruby edges and an average size tan head. Aroma of spices, yeast, citrus, and dark fruit. The flavor is sweet, citrus, spices, and dark fruit. Decent body, good brew.

Smooth caramel, vanilla, and a pleasent metalic aroma.  Pours brown/dark amber with a huge long lasting off white head.  Heavy caramel malt, brown sugar, chocolate and creamy vanilla.   Spicy notes, cinamon and a lot nutmeg.   wow a lot going on, great beer!

750 ml. bottle...very carbonated, average brown Belgian, good at first sip but watery and bland aftertaste, more flavor would be good. This bottle I drank before aging so I may try again some other time.

Rated at the Pewaukee Tasting II 5/5/07.
Pale cloudy brown, massive head 3-finer head if not carefully poured 
Aroma  dust, lemon, Belgian yeast, fresh
Flavor  Lightly sour, very mild, some of the aroma characteristics, yeasty
Palate  Medium-bodied

Bottle (750 ml) at work. Unclear red/brown - offwhite head. Aroma: Fruiyyeasty, light flowery. Taste: Fruity, yeasty, berries, caramel, brown sugar, sweetness, dark bread. It is a typical belgian dubbel, but just a bit too plain and simple - it needs some complexity !!
Bottle. Red brown colour with a beige head. Flavour is cellar notes, alcohol, caramel, fruit, malt, candis sugar, yeast, dried fruit. Very nice beer.

750 ml bottle labeled as Grotten Bruin - Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head that stays well and laces the glass. Aromas of yeast, caramel, and some dark fruits, mainly raisins.  Flavor is yeasty as well with lots of caramel too.  A touch of cherry shows through but mainly this is malty.   Just a bit of hops before the finish.  Smooth and sweet on the palate.  Like a good piece of candy.  Pretty tasty overall..

Pours a dark, cloudy brown with an orange hue that shines bleakly through under bright light. The head is thick and light tan and composed of medium to large bubbles. The head fades into an uneven layer that looks like islands and peninsulas in the glass, jutting from the glass. The aroma is very heavy with toffee-like malts. There is also a significant aroma of yeast, fruit (macerated pears, banana), and spice (allspice with hints of nutmeg). After smelling it several times, some tart fruit begins to show through, too (dark, sour cherries). The flavor begins very malty and full-bodied on the tip of the tongue with a hint of funk (dry, dusty taste - perhaps brettanomyces?). The front of the tongue also detects some bitter hops,  more malts, and some spices (cloves, peppercorn). The malt profile remains spicy throughout - which, along with the carbonation, tickles and slightly stings the entire length of the tongue. The middle of the tongue detects more dry dust, sweet malts and molasses, some spice, and hints of alcohol. The finish is full-bodied and mostly sweet but with a spicy bite, a bit of sherry wine, and a touch of bitter hops on the very back of the tongue. The mouthfeel is tingly from carbonation but overall thick and dusty. A very special beer - quite nice.
Bottled. Poured dark copper, with a tan head. Sour nose and a malty, sour, earthy flavor. The finish was sweet and flavorful.

Hazy light brown look with a bubbling light brown head. Complex "tasty" aroma of different esters along with sweet honney and spices like cloves and pepper. Extremly exploding mouthfull, in a good way, allows the complex flavor to come through. Flavor is belgian style yeasty sweetness and differint spices, again pepper. Very nice

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2013 750ml bottle. Golden reddish body with a dense off-white/light beige head. Pleasant and delicate aroma of malt and caramel. Flavor is very malty in a well composed way, dry fruit (fig), sweet and spicy. A nice and full bodied beer for relaxing moments.

Translucent amber brown in color with a lasting tan cellophane lining on the head. Sweet, candied beets come out with honey almonds, brown sugared bran flakes, steel and honey wheat bread. Heavily effervescence with sweet hazelnuts cased with brown sugar. Biscuity, whole wheat sweetness comes out in the finish, leavened with light almond butter and complete doughy composures. Aged noble hoppings create a clean numbing feel. The sweet wheat backdrop gets complimented by a maple biscuit batter. Caramel cubes once melting, now hardened and solidified on a honey wafer base. Dry body and finish, accentuated when the carbonation subsides. Sweetened jojoba comes clean with a talc and cocoa edge.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2009 Bottle, 75cl corked. Poured unclear, golden-red to orange, with a nice beige head. Quite sweet nose with dried fruits and some alcohol. Sweet and malty flavor with caramel, hops and spices. Quite fizzy, full body. Quite lovely creation. Next time I buy a bottle, I will certainly cellar it, guess theres potential for lagering it. Rating: 7-4-7-4-16-3.8. 070430Bottle, 75cl. Its a hazy, orange-brown beer with a small, off-white head. Dried fruits, sweetness, alcohol, malts, cellar notes and a light hint of oxidation in the aroma. The flavor has caramel, dried fruits, sweetness, some alcohol and a herbal bitterness. Full-bodied and nicely carbonated. The finish is much like the initial flavor, but on the bitter side. A really nice Belgian. 090710

Pours to a dark rusty orange body with a lively off-white head.  Nice lacing.  The aroma is dusty, Belgian yeasts, bananas, brown malts, seems to have some smoked malt.  The flavor is very yeasty with malts and bananas.  Bready doughs.  The palate is extremely effervescent.  Carbonation all over the place.  Surprising.
deep browncoloured ale , ovaltine malt nose, malty flavour rich with a hint of ovaltine

750ml bottle. Pours a hazy brown/amber with a large light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of caramel, plums, yeast spice, and sweet malt. Taste is the same but is more spicy than sweet. Mouthfeel is a little thin with a mild bitterness. A good easy drinking Dubbel.
Tap at Bonte Koe, Leiden, Netherlands: Dark Brown ale from a lagering site at Belgian cave.

[Sampled several times some years ago, 2003/04.]

Has its own flavor of caramel, yeast, spices, hops and much more. A very complex beer, which was one of my favorites and could be it again, if I shouldnt  taste all beer in the world. Fresh and with a high drinkability!
This beer lacks the special taste that makes really something outstanding. The aroma falls a bit flat, the malts have an almost  bland quality to them.  Not the best, worth a try though

The aroma has spice, caramel, hops, and dark fruit. The appearance is light brown/red with a large head. The flavor is like the aroma with lots of sweet and a little bitter. The palate is a little thin. Overall its a very good beer.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour with a large tan head. Sweet spicy aroma, a bit like Leffe Brune. Spicy flavour with some sweetness. Carbonation is slighly too high.

On tap at the Happy Gnome.  Dirty copper color with a large white raft.  Aromas of toffee and dark rum.  I taste pasty tomato, plum and purple grape.  Some molasses.  Very strange flavors.  Quite deep and resonant, with an elusive rich palate.  An odd duck.
Dark brown ale, beige lasting head. Sweet aroma with red fruits (plums?). Sweet malts. Medium complex aroma with muscovado sugar, rum?, plums/prunes and notes of yeast. Nice.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Tap. Pours with a dark brown almost black color. Aromas of plums and citrus. Flavor of dark fruit such as plums and a bit of strawberry. Some bready yeast in the background that is not very prominent. Medium bodied, nice finish.

0.25l bottle, from the big Grottenbier tulip at the Hopdevil in Zagreb Poured s nice (very) dark red, almost black. Medium to small beige creamy head. The nose is damn strong and assertive. Grapes, raisins, alcohol, bakers yeast. Quite vinuous, but not exactly pleasant. The taste is nice, sweet. Quite malty, yeasty, notes of gummi bears. Trace hints of hops. Smooth, and the taste isnt all that full. Almost stale grape aftertaste.  Very good, but not all that spectacular.
Pours a dark brown with a medium creamy head.  Sweet start that moves to a slight bitterness with a nice spice to it.  Rates pretty high among the style in flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2007 Tasted 2007-03-11. 5 year old bottle, 33cl. The aroma rose out of the bottle, and despite somewhat unpleasant notes of metal and soap, it was quite delightfull. It appeared muddy - dark brown colour. Frothy, off-white head that lasted a couple of minutes. Very complex flavour. I could taste the age in a good way. Unfortunately there was still a hint of metal in the finish, but only in the first couple of sips. Then just pleasure.

Bottled. Dark brown in colour, a minor beige creamy head. The aroma is fruity, dried fruits with a sweet  scent to it. The flavour is on the dry side with a rich carbonation that can be felt on the tip of the tongue. There is a fruity taste.
Bottle: Brown clear amber with creamy off white head. Sweet caramel and nut aroma. Awesome sweet candy roasted nut malt with a slightly diffrent than most brown belgiums must be the aging process.

On tap at Flying Pie Boise,
Pours out a very dark ruby red topped with a small off white head. Aroma and tast of sweet, caramel, and some yeast.
Pretty good.

Pours a ruddy opaque brown with an ample light and light tan head, subsiding slowly.  The nose is subtle.  Laced with chocolate a rich malty sweetness, and just a touch of that Belgian funk as well as some lactobacillis smelling notes, perhaps more so.  The mouthfeel is smooth rich and creamy.  The flavors are certainly not disappointing.  Creamy and rich malt, slight hints of chocolate, more so caramel malt, though balanced by that yogurty Lactobacillis sort of flavor.  A bit fruity, creamy rich finish.  Theres a bit of a tartness and fruitiness in the aftertaste.  I really enjoyed this beer and would gladly drink more of this.  Not a lot of complexity, but man is it nicely formed.

(Bottle) Pours hazy redish brown. Sweet caramell/candy aroma with some (dark) fruits, yeast and notes of spices. Light undertones of cherries, rum/raisins and dark bread/dark malt. Medium sweet, well carbonated but soft mouthfeel. Light caramelly flavour with allmond paste sweetness and earthy undertones. Just a touch of hops and hints of dark bread and spices. Medium body.

(25.4oz bottle):  Pours a huge head, light brownish.  Active & bubbly.  Lasting head, good lacing.  Brownish coppery color.  Enticing.  Sweet aroma, some kind of sweet fruit, ripe green grapes or something light, floweay...cant name it.  Intriguing.  Good belgian taste.  Flowery taste.  Light tasting, refreshing.  Not as complex, but tasty.

Pours dark bronze with a soapy thick tan head.  The aroma has dark fruits, raisins, earth, yeastiness, lightly toasted malt and cola aspects.  Medium bodied thats lighter than expected with sharp spritzy carbonation.  Flavor starts with toasty malt, dark fruits from the aroma - mainly raisins and figs, and a good amount of earthiness.  The finish has some hop spice and some astringency.  Nice dubbel.

Heres a find.  Huge thick tan head, very sticky and coarse, leaving a significant amount of lacing on the glass.  Very bright, sweet, fruity aromas with pear, apple, peach, and cherry notes.  A delicate spiciness (nutmeg, cinnamon), along with a sweet malt and candy-like base.  Flavors were similarly bright and crisp, though slightly sour, with apples and pears coming to the forefront.  Sweet malts, bready yeast, and a hint of hops complemented the overall sweetness of this brew.  The spiciness was present, but was of a mysterious and undefined nature.  The mouthfeel was silky and velvety, and the carbonation produced a slight prickly feeling on the tongue.  Nice bitter and dry finish, creating a very well-rounded, complex, and balanced experience.  Really nice stuff.

A beautiful pour, time after time from the endless 750ml bottle... well-hazed bronze (fine sediment, mild carbonation) topped with a pearly, ecru head that held thick and clung in a sticky sheet. Aromas are woodsy, tart, yeasty, yogurty, cherries (not sweet), mild vinegar and alcohol. Flavor has an annoying metallic quality that does not disperse. Otherwise, a creamy mouth carries a flavorful melange of fruity yeasts and malts with enough tartness to initiate those looking for an introductory "Sour". <font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL 60462</font>

Impressively headed murky chestnut specimen. Sweet, dank, licorice-and- soy sauce snout. Smells decidedly cooked and foody. A sourish hint of Rodenbachs barrelly strangeness. Medium sweet caramel malt with a restrained Orval-like herbal note lurking in the background. That tangily metallic sensation on the tongue again. A creamily smooth and tasty hybrid of Flemish sour ale and Dubbel. More beers should be brewed in caves.
Draught > Gingerman. Good appearnace & good fruity cherry aroma. Nice creamy palate. Very drinakble and tasty.

(33 cl bottle at The Rover, Göteborg) Clear dark red color, dense tan head. Acidic to sour, some Belgian ale yeast also, scent. Spicy and a bit yeasty and alcohol taste. Sweet aftertaste. Medium bitterness, spritzy mouthfeel.

Bottle, 33 cl.  A couple of months past "best-before"-date.. Good, solid dark Belgian ale (perhaps the most atypical dubbel sampled so far), wonderful nose, lacking in flavour and palate though. Wonderful Bretty note lingering in background.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2010 Draft at the FW GingerMan.  Pours a dark brown with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of light caramel, leaves, some vinegar, and light cocoa.  Great yeast presence.  FIrst thing I notice is actually the wonderfully creamy body, and its not as high-carbonated as expected.  Great for me.  Tastes of sugar, pear, grapes, earthy dust, and a light sour taste.  Finishes dry and pretty full, with some roast and an almost salty/sour taste.  I couldnt help but notice the very light sour tones in this beer, mainly cause it was giving me flashbacks to my first gueuze and flemish sour beers.  But I like the sourness here, cause it was so much lighter and fit with the beer, rather than completely overtaking it.  This beer loses some points for not having quite enough flavor to justify the creamy and almost thick texture, and not tasting all that unique in the malts.  But the yeast flavors and body were wonderful.


This beer loses points for nothing other than not being perfect.  The flavor is all there, and it ages with grace.  My original rating was from tap, but Im revising my rating with a bottle nearby.  Malt flavor MAY be a little light, but the flavor is so seemless and fascinating, I dont care.  Greatness.
Bottle. Brown with thin white head. Spicy aroma with dried fruit. Flavour is a little sweet (brown sugar) and malty, spicy, with yeasty notes. Perhaps a little thin.
Bottle. Amber-brown an off-white head Malty, spicy, yeasty and roasty aroma. Flavour is nicely bready and malty with yeast, corriander, bit chocolate, nutty and nice sweetness.
Smells okay, looks nice. Taste is just okay, not overall spicy, and not amazing in flavor. Kind of an average doulbe to me.

Bottle conditioned, 330ml, aged 4 yrs. Chestnut brown with white head. Thickish sweetish Bruin with plenty of presence of roasted malt and a herbal spiciness. There is a tartness in the background, presumably from the ageing and a hazelnut type dryness on the finish. Quite accomplished overall.
